stories.text: I am frustrated with doing file searches on MacOS. I used to love mdfind. It was so fast and gave me hits on everything no matter where I was in a directory. Parts of filename, or something in the file would show up on mdfind. Now it's like not giving a search. I copied the exact filename and not a hit. I tried using the regular smart folder setting it to show recent images created, modified, and opened. Fiddled around with that after changing it to 2 days I got two results. But there should be three! And even when I put down 1 day it would not show up even when it was created "Today" it should have shown up in search. The search function is totally obfuscated and I'm at loss to figure out a reliable search method for this computer. MacOS running 11.3.1
stories.title: Tips how to understand search on smart folders? or terminal's mdfind command?
Senate must back creation of ‘Space National Guard’ to end a needless division

stories.text:
They appear in daily newspapers (including the San Francisco Chronicle). Here's an example.

http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2021/12/08/when-a-newspaper-publishes-an-unsolvable-puzzle/

But there's dozens of solutions. I understand a computer could eventually calculate them all. My question is how everyday newspaper readers can solve them with just a pen and paper.

The totals for the rows still leave many, many possibilities. Is the idea to just start trying numbers, and then backtracking again and again, until eventually you stumble on a winning path?
stories.title: Ask HN: Can you solve “Challenger” puzzles?
Generate AI image from simple sketch
Payments firm Stripe cuts internal valuation by 28%

stories.text:
I've recently asked if it's time to revisit the decision to make structs in maps in Go mutable, and was politely declined, with a reference to this being a refusted proposal since 2012:

https://github.com/golang/go/issues/53857

Since arrays work fine, if a is a slice or an array:

a[10].field = 42

it seems bogus that maps don't; this doesn't compile in Go if m is a map:

m[10].field = 42

In both cases, the address of the struct is calculated at runtime, as it must be known to access the field.

Instead of leaving this as a rant, let's make it a question: what's your "what is this insanity?" peeve with your favourite language?
stories.title: Go refusing to make structs in maps mutable since 2012
ECB Says Bitcoin Ban “Probable” Due to Climate Concerns
ScyllaDB V open source NoSQL database embraces WebAssembly
Heather Meeker: OSS Investment Should Be Recognized as an ESG Investment
